No. 2 pencils (fat grip for K,1 students)
Washable Markers
Colored Pencils
Crayons
Glue sticks (2)
A pencil box holder
Erasers
Pencil sharpeners
Black dry erasers (3-4)
mini dry erase board eraser or cloth

Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS) is pleased to announce that beginning on June 15th, the district will continue to distribute meals throughout the summer months at three locations: Silver Lake Elementary School (TCAPS), Long Lake Elementary School - TCAPS and Traverse Heights Elementary School - TCAPS.

Nutritious bagged meals will continue to be distributed through August 31st. The East Middle School location will close for the summer after the Friday, June 12th meal distribution.

TCAPS will continue meal distributions on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. The distribution sites are open from 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and location addresses are: Long Lake Elementary School (7600 N. Long Lake Rd.), Silver Lake Elementary School (5858 Culver Rd.), and Traverse Heights Elementary School (933 Rose St.).

Additional distributions of items to support families during this time will continue to occur during the summer as well, as long as supplies are available, and as pop-up pantries and other item distributions are coordinated at the sites.

post_text: If you have a young child at home who will turn five between July 1st and December 1st of this year, the Young Fives program may be just the program for your family. Young Fives follows the school year calendar and is a five day, full day program provided at no cost to families. Openings are available at Silver Lake Elementary School (TCAPS) (933.3580) and Courtade Elementary School - TCAPS (933.5800). For more information, contact the schools directly or visit www.tcaps.net/kindergarten.

post_text: Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS) is pleased to announce that Traverse City Central High School - TCAPS student, Elizabeth Saunders, has received the 2020 Michigan High School Athletic Association (MHSAA) Scholar-Athlete Award. Saunders is in her fourth season of Alpine skiing and is a three-year varsity rower. She also played freshman volleyball. In addition to her athletic accomplishments, Saunders, won the Congressional App Challenge for the development of the CalcuSaver app and serves as president of TechGirls, a group of students that helps women and minorities pursue STEM education. Saunders plans to attend Stanford University to study computer science and business. To learn more about the MHSAA Scholar-Athlete Awards, visit: https://secondhalf.mhsaa.com/All-News/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/8910/Scholars-Athletes-2020-Class-A.

Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS) offers Career and Technical Education (CTE) opportunities at Traverse City Central High School - TCAPS and Traverse City West Senior High School (TCAPS). TCAPS offers a few select CTE courses on site, which are in addition to the opportunities offered at Traverse Bay Area Intermediate School District (TBAISD)’s Career-Tech Center. Programs at the high schools are one hour per day and allow for flexibility for students who want to participate in CTE experiences, but otherwise could not fit a half day attendance at the Career-Tech Center into their schedule. CTE courses offered at the high school are in the following areas of study:

Business, Marketing and Finance
Engineering, Architecture & Design
Computer Science & Programming
Radio and TV Broadcasting - Available at CHS only

post_text: Teams from Traverse City West Senior High School (TCAPS) participated in the 2020 Academic World Quest regional competition on Thursday, February 6, 2020, at the campus of Northwestern Michigan College (NMC). The "Temple Runners,” Alex Eveleigh, Ryan Hozak, Brennan Burns and Michael Riccobono, from TC West won the competition and have earned the opportunity to travel to Washington, DC, to compete in the national competition on April 25, 2020. One of the best parts of our job is getting to meet people like Crystal Gober, the founder and creator of Socks Of Love. Crystal came to our office yesterday with 16 pairs of boots, 15 pairs of boys athletic pants, 28 pairs of leggings, 110 pair of underwear, 152 pairs of socks, and 6 pairs of snow pants.

Just as Crystal was leaving we got a call from one of our elementary schools asking if we had any pants for a boy in great need. Her timing could not have been more perfect. And now a young boy will have warm, comfortable brand new pants for his holiday break.

A full-time realtor, Crystal also spends part of her year making Sock Snowmen to sell. In return, 100% of the proceeds is donated to area non-profits. We were only one of her many stops this week! Over the past 5 years, Socks of Love has raised $27,240 for local charities.

Thank you very much to GT County's Matt McKinley for connecting us! And thank you Crystal for your kindness and goodwill towards those in need.

The Traverse City Central High School - TCAPS Debate Team competed in the Michigan Interscholastic Forensics Association State Finals for Policy and Public Forum Debate. Team members include: Henry Huschke, Shane Taylor, Regan O’Connor, Erin O’Donnell, Ethan Schweitzer, and Luke Appleford. State finals for competitive debate is a rigorous tournament that involves a significant amount of research, speaking drills, and preparation on the part of the competitors.

Varsity members Henry Huschke and Shane Taylor led the preliminary rounds in the policy tournament with a perfect 5-0 record. Huschke and Taylor went on to win 3rd Place in the state for Varsity Policy Debate. Huschke also finished 3rd in Individual Speaking. In Public Forum Debate, Erin O’Donnell and Regan O’Connor finished with a 4-1 record, placing 5th in the state. Individual speaking awards for Public Forum Debate went to Regan O’Connor, 8th Place, Erin O’Donnell, 11th Place, and Ethan Schweitzer, 27th Place.

Congratulations, Trojan Debate!

Traverse City West Senior High School (TCAPS) Advanced Photography and Photojournalism students shared the amazing pictures they took at the recent Native American Heritage Symposium held at the school.

The Native American Heritage Symposium was an opportunity for students to learn about and celebrate Native American culture, history, and heritage and to break down stereotypes and racism while building compassion, empathy, understanding, and respect for a culture that is often misrepresented or underrepresented in mainstream media and in education. TCAPS educators Samantha TwoCrow, Mary Kay Hicks and Heidi Gregory collaborated to organize this event. Presenters included Native American students from West Senior High, Suttons Bay Schools, and Northport Schools along with many Native American community members. Symposium topics included culture, education, dance and music, history and more.
